englishTitle: TheBook of Quinte Essence: orThe Fifth Being;: That is to say,Man's Heaven.: A tretice in englisch breuely drawe out of þe book of quintiseessencijs in latyn, þat hermys þe prophete andkyng of Egipt, after þe flood of Noefadir of philosophris, hadde byreuelacioun of an aungil|of god to himsende.

0.1:
With þe my&yogh;t, wisdom, & grace of þe holy trynite, I write |to &yogh;ou a tretice in englisch breuely drawe out of þe|book of quintis essencijs in latyn, þat hermys þe prophete and|kyng of Egipt, after the flood of Noe, fadir of philosophris,|hadde by reuelacioun of an aungil of god to him sende, þat|þe wijsdom and þe science of þis book schulde not perische,|but be kept and preserued vnto þe eende of þe world, of alle|holy men from al wickid peple and tyrauntis, for greet perilis|þat my&yogh;te falle þerof.  For wiþiune þis breue tretis, wiþ þe|grace of god, I wole more determine of practif practise, MS. Harl. þan of theorik.|&yogh;itt ben boþe nedeful / The firste and souereyneste priuyte þat|god, maker of kynde, ordeyned for mannys nede, how þat olde|euangelik men, and feble in kynde, my&yogh;te be restorid, and haue|a&yogh;en her firste strenkþis of &yogh;ongþe in þe same degree þat is in|al kynde, & be mad hool parfi&yogh;tly, except þe strok of þe|þundir blast, & violent brusuris, and oppressynge of to myche|betynge / Also perilous fallyngis of hi&yogh; placis, to myche abstynence,|& oþere yuel gouernaunce a&yogh;ens kynde, And also þe|teerme þat is sett of god, þat noman may a-schape, as Iob seiþ in|latyn / "Breues dies hominis sunt &c.;"  Forsoþe philosophoris
 |clepen þe purest substaunce of manye corruptible þingis elementid,|'quinta essencia,' þat is to seie, 'mannys heuene,' drawe out|by craft of mani; ? MS. meant for 'man.' for whi, as quinta essencia superior, þat is,|heuene of oure lord god, in reward of þe .iiij elementis, is| yncorruptible & vnchaungeable / ri&yogh;t so quinta essencia superior|inferior, þat is to seie, mannys heuene, is incorruptible,|in reward of þe .4. qualitees of mannys body; and so it is|preued naturaly þat oure quinta essencia, þat is, mannes heuene,|in it- MS. siff silf is incorruptible; and so it is not hoot and drie wiþ|fier / ne coold and moist wiþ watir / ne hoot & moist with eyr,|ne coold and drie wiþ erþe; but oure quinta essencia avayliþ to|þe contrarie, as heuene incorruptible / But vndirstonde þat oure|qui[n]ta essencia is nou&yogh;t so incorruptible as is heuene of oure|lord god; but it is incorruptible in reward of composicioun|maad of þe .4. elementis; & it hath .iij. names by the philosophoris,|þat is to seie / brennynge watir / þe soule in þe spirit of|wyn, & watir of lijf / But whanne &yogh;e wole concelle it, þanne|schal &yogh;e clepe it 'oure quinta essencia'; for þis name, & þe|nature þerof, ri&yogh;t fewe philosophoris wolde schewe / but sikurly|þei biriede þe truþe with hem. and witiþ weel that it is clepid|brennynge watir; and it is no brennyng watir: forwhi, it is not|moist ne coold as comoun watir; for it brenneþ, & so doiþ not|comyn watir; ne it is nat hoot and moist as eir, for eir corrumpiþ|a þing a-noon, as it schewiþ weel by generacioun of flies,|& areins, and siche oþere; but sikirly þis is alwey incorruptible,|if it be kept cloos fro fli&yogh;t / Also it is not coold and drie as erþe.|for souereynly it worchiþ & chaungiþ.  And it is not hoot and|drie as fier, as it schewiþ by experience; for hoot þingis it keliþ,|& hoot sijknessis it doiþ awey / Also þat it &yogh;eueþ incorruptibilite,| and kepiþ a þing fro corruptibilite and rotynge, it is preued|þus / Forwhi. what pece of fleisch, fisch, or deed brid, be putt|þerinne, it schal not corru[m]pe ne rote whilis it is þerinne /|miche more þanne it wole kepe quyk fleisch of mannys body|from al manere corruptibilite and rotynge / This is oure quinta|essencia, þat is to seie, mannys heuene, þat god made to þe conseruacioun
 |of þe .4. qualitees of mannys body, ri&yogh;t as he made|his heuene to þe conseruacioun of al þe world / And wite &yogh;e for|certeyn þat manye philosophoris and lechis þat ben now, knowe|nou&yogh;t þis quinta essencia, ne þe truþe þerof / Forwhi; god wole|not þat þei knowe it; for her greet brennynge coueitise &|vicious lyuynge / Forsoþe quinta essencia superior, þat is to seie,|heuene of oure lord god bi him silf / Aloone / &yogh;eueþ not conseruacioun|in þe world, and wondirful influence, but by þe vertue|of þe sunne, planetis, and oþere sterris; ri&yogh;t so oure quinta|essencia, þat is, mannys heuene, wole be maad fair wiþ þe sunne|mineralle, fynyd, schynynge, incorruptibile; and euene in qualite|þat fier may not appeire, corrumpe, ne distroie. and þis is verry|gold of þe myn, of þe erþe, or of þe floodis gaderid / for gold of|alkamy maad with corosyues distroieþ kynde, as aristotle and|manye oþere philosophoris prouen / and þerfore good gold naturel,|& of þe myn of þe erþe, is clepid of philosophoris 'sol' in|latyn; for he is þe sonne of oure heuene, lich as sol þe planet is|in þe heuene aboue; for þis planete &yogh;eueþ to gold his influence,|nature, colour, & a substaunce incorruptible.  And oure quinta|essencia, mannys heuene, is of þe nature & þe colour of heuene / |And oure sol, þat is, fyn gold of þe myne, schal make it fair, ri&yogh;t|as sol þe planete makiþ heuene fair / and so þese two togidere|ioyned schal &yogh;eue influence in us, and þe condiciouns of heuene|and of heuenly sonne / in as miche as it is possible in deedly|nature, conseruacioun and restorynge of nature lost, & renewynge|of &yogh;ongþe / And it schal &yogh;eue plenteuously heelþe: and so it|is preued by astronomy aboue, þat sterris þat haþ influence vpon|þe heed and þe necke of man / as ben þe sterris of aries, taurus,|and gemini, &yogh;euen influence syngulerly vpon Gerapigra galieni /|And þerfore it haþ a synguler strenkþe, by þe ordynaunce of|god, to drawe awey þe superflue humouris fro þe heed, þe necke,|and þe brest, and not fro þe membris byneþe / And so I seie of|spicis þat drawiþ humouris fro þe knees, þe leggis, and þe feet,|þat resseyuen a synguler influence of þe sterris of Capricorn,|Aquarie and pisces, & ri&yogh;t so of oþere, et cetera / Comounne|&yogh;e not þis book of deuyne secretes to wickid men and auerous;
 |but kepe &yogh;e it in priuytee / Take þe beste wiyn þat &yogh;e may|fynde, if &yogh;e be of power; & if &yogh;e be ri&yogh;t pore, þanne take|corrupt wiyn, þat is, rotyn, of a watery humour, but not egre,|þat is, sour, for þe quint essencia þerof is naturaly incorruptible|þe which &yogh;e schal drawe out by sublymacioun / And þanne|schal þer leue in þe ground of þe vessel þe .4. elementis, as it|were, rotun fecis of wiyn / But firste &yogh;e muste distille þis wiyn|.7. tymes; & þanne haue &yogh;e good brennynge watir / Forsoþe,| þis is þe watri mater fro which is drawe oure quinta essencia /|Thanne muste &yogh;e do make in þe furneis of aischin, a distillatorie|of glas al hool of oo. pece, wiþ an hoole a-boue in þe heed, where|þe watir schal be putt yn, and be take out / And þis is a|wondirful instrument þat þat þing þat by vertues of fier ascendith|and distillith wiþinne þe vessel, per canales brachiales, þat is, by|pipis lich to armys, be bore a&yogh;en, and eftsoones ascendith, &|eft descendiþ contynuely day and ny&yogh;t, til þe brennynge water|heuenly be turned into quintam essenciam / And so bi continuelle|ascenciouns & discenciouns, þe quinta essencia is|departid fro þe corruptible composicioun of þe .4. elementis.|For bifore þat þing þat is twies sublymed is more glorified, and|is more sotil, and fer from þe corrumpcioun of þe .4. elementis|more separat þan whanne it ascendith but oonys; and so vnto|a þousand tymes, so þat by contynuel ascendynge and descendynge,|by the which it is sublymed to so myche hi&yogh;nes of glorificacioun,|it schal come þat it schal be a medicyn incorruptible|almoost as heuene aboue, and of þe nature of heuene / And|þerfore oure quinta essencia worþily is clepid 'mannys heuene' /|And aftir manye daies þat it hath be in þis sotil vessel of glas|distillid / &yogh;e schulen opene þe hoole of þe vessel in þe heed þat|was selid with þe seel of lute of wijsdom, maad of þe sotillest|flour, and of white of eyren, and of moist papere, ymeyngid so|þat no þing respire out / And whane &yogh;e opene þe hoole. if þer|come out a passynge heuenly swete flauour þat alle men þat| come yn naturely drawe þerto. þanne &yogh;e haue oure quinta|essencia / and ellis sele þe vessel, and putte it to þe fier a&yogh;en|til &yogh;e haue it.
0.2: And anoþer maner worchinge of oure quinta essencia is|þis / Take þe noblest and þe strengest brennynge watir þat &yogh;e|may haue distillid out of pure my&yogh;ty wiyn, and putte it into|a glas clepid amphora, with a long necke / and close þe mouþ|strongly wiþ wex; And loke þat half or þe þridde part be fulle;|and birie it al in hors dounge, preparate as it is seid hereafter /|so þat þe necke of þe glas be turned dounward, & þe botum|be turned vpward, þat by vertu of þe hors dounge þe quinta|essencia ascende vp to þe botum.  And þe grosté of þe mater|of þe watir descende dounward to þe necke / And aftir manye|daies, whanne &yogh;e take it out, softly lift vp þe glas as it stondith,|and &yogh;e schal se in þickenes and cleernesse a difference bitwene|þe quintam essenciam sublymed, and þe grose mater þat is in þe|necke / þe wondirful maistry of departynge of þat oon fro þat|oþer is þis / Take a scharp poyntel, or a pricke of yren, &|peerse into þe wex þat hongiþ in þe mouþ of þe glas a&yogh;ens þe|erþe / and whanne &yogh;e haue peersid al fully to þe watir, take out|þe poyntel or þe pricke / And þat erþely watir wole first come|out þat is in þe necke / and so til it be come out vnto þe|departinge bitwixe it / and þe quinte essence, þat is, mannys|heuene sublymed. and whane &yogh;e se þat þis quint essence wole|renne & melte aftir þat þis erþely watir be voydid, putte þanne|swiftly &yogh;oure fyngir to þe hoole, & turne vp þe glas, and þanne|&yogh;e haue þerinne oure quinte essence, and þe erþely watir wiþoute |aside.  And þis is a passyng souereyn priuytee.
0.3: The þridde maner is, þat &yogh;e take a greet glas clepid amphora,|and seele it weel, and birie it weel in þe wombe of an hors al|togidere. and þe pureté of þe quinte essencie schal be sublymed|aboue, & þe grosté schal abide byneþe in þe botme / take out|softli þat þat fletiþ a-boue; and þat þat leeueþ bihynde, putte it|to þe fier.
0.4:
The .iiij. maner is þis. take what vessel of glas þat &yogh;e wole,|or of erþe strongly glasid, and þer-vpon a round foot of glas|wiþ a leg. and seele þe vessel with his couertour, þat þe rod|of þe foot of þe glas wiþinne þe vessel honge in þe eyr, þat þat|þing þat ascendith to þe couertour in þe maner of a pott boilynge
 |descende doun a&yogh;en by þe foot of þe glas. and this instrument|may &yogh;e do make wiþoute greet cost / The fifþe maner is, þat þe|brennynge water be .10 tymes distillid in hors dounge contynuely|digest.
0.5: The science of makynge of fier wiþoute fier / wherby &yogh;e|may make oure quinte essence wiþoute cost or traueile, and|withoute occupacioun and lesynge of tyme / Take þe beste horse|dounge þat may be had þat is weel digest, and putte it wiþine|a uessel, or ellis a pitt maad wiþ þe erþe anoyntid þoru&yogh;out with|past maad of aischin.  And in þis vessel or pitt, bete weel togidere|þe dounge; And in þe myddil of þis doung, sette þe vessel of|distillacioun vnto þe myddis or more / For it is nede þat al þe|heed of þe vessel be in þe coold eir / þat, þat þing þat bi vertu|of þe fier of þe doung þat ascendith þerby be turned into watir by vertu of cooldnes of þe eir and falle doun a&yogh;en and ascende|vp a&yogh;en and þus &yogh;e haue fier wiþoute fier, and but wiþ litil|traueile.
0.6: Also anoþer maner of fier. sette &yogh;oure vessel forseid to þe|strong reuerberacioun of þe sunne in somer tyme, and lete it|stonde þere ny&yogh;t and day.
0.7:
Here I wole teche &yogh;ou how pore euangelik men may haue|wiþoute cost, and almoost for nou&yogh;t, þe gracious influence of|gold, and þe maner of þe fixynge of it in oure heuene, þat is,|oure quinta essencia. if &yogh;e be pore, &yogh;e schal preie a riche man|þat is &yogh;oure freend to leene &yogh;ou a good floreyn of florence / and|anele it vpon a plate of yren as yren is anelid. and haue biside|&yogh;ou a uessel of erþe glasid, fillid ful of the beste brennynge watir|þat &yogh;e may fynde. & caste into þe watir þe floreyn anelid. and|loke þat &yogh;e haue a sotilte and a slei&yogh;þe to quenche sodeynly þe|fier, þat þe watir waaste not; and be weel war þat non yren touche|þe watir.  but af[t]er caste into þe watir þe floreyn, and do so .l.|tymes or more, for þe oftere þe bettere it is / And if &yogh;e se þat þe|watir waaste to myche, chaunge it þanne, and take newe, & do|so ofte tymes. and whanne &yogh;e haue do &yogh;oure quenchour, putte|alle þe watris togidere / And &yogh;e schulen vndirstonde þat þe|vertu of brennynge watir is sich þat naturely it drawiþ out of
 |gold alle þe vertues & propirtees of it, & it holdiþ incorrumptibiletee|& an euene heete. þanne meynge þis brennynge |watir þus giltid wiþ oure quinte essence, and vse it.  but be war|þat &yogh;e quenche not þe floreyn in oure quinte essence; for þanne|it were lost / And if it so be þat &yogh;e haue not þis brennynge watir|redy, þanne quenche &yogh;oure floreyn in þe beste whi&yogh;t wiyn þat|may be had / For sikirly þe philosophore seiþ, þat wiyn hath|also þe propirtee to restreyne in it þe influence and vertues of|gold / And whanne &yogh;e haue do &yogh;oure werk, &yogh;e schal wite þat þe|floreyn is als good, & almoost of þe same wei&yogh;te, as it was|afore / þerfore vse wiyn or brennynge watir giltid, so þat &yogh;e may|be hool, and wexe glad, and be &yogh;ong.  And þus &yogh;e haue oure|heuene, and þe sunne in him fixid, to þe conseruacioun of mannys|nature and fixacioun of oure heuene, þat is, oure quinte|essence.
0.8: The science how &yogh;e schule gilde more my&yogh;tily by brennynge|watir or wiyn þan I tau&yogh;te you tofore, wherby þe water or|þe wiyn schal take to it my&yogh;tily þe influence & þe vertues|of fyne gold.
0.9:
Take þe calx of fyn gold as it is declarid here-aftir in þis|book, and putte it in a siluer spone, and anele it at þe fier.|& þanne caste þe cals of the gold in þe brennynge watir|or in wiyn .1. tymes, as I tau&yogh;te &yogh;ou tofore wiþ þe floreyn.  and|&yogh;e schule haue &yogh;oure licour by an hundrid part bettir gilt þan &yogh;e|had tofore wiþ þe floreyn / Forwhi. fier worchiþ more strongly|and bettere in sotil parties þan it doiþ in an hool plate / And |also brennynge watir or wiyn drawiþ out more my&yogh;tily bi a|þousand part þe propirtees of gold fro smale parties anelid, þan|it doiþ fro a þicke plate / And &yogh;e schal vndirstonde þat wiyn|not aloonly holdiþ in it þe propirtees of gold, but myche more|þe propirtees of alle liquibles if þei be quenchid þerinne. and þat|is a souereyn priuite: Forwhi, if &yogh;e quenche saturne liquified|in wiyn or in comoun watir .7. tymes, and aftirward in þat wiyn|or watir &yogh;e quenche mars manye tymes, þanne mars schal take|algate þe neischede and þe softnes of saturne / And þe same|schal venus do, & alle oþere liquibles / or ellis, And &yogh;e
 |quenche mars in whi&yogh;t wiyn or in comoun watir manye tymes,|and aftirward in þe same wiyn or watir &yogh;e caste saturne liquified|ofte tymes, þanne wiþoute doute &yogh;e schal fynde þat þe saturne|is maad ri&yogh;t hard / Therfore þe propirtees of alle liquibles may|be brou&yogh;t into wiyn or watir; but myche more my&yogh;tily into|brennynge watir good and precious.
0.10: The science to make a fier, þat is, wiþoute cole, withoute|lyme, wiþoute li&yogh;t, worchinge a&yogh;ens al maner scharpnes or|accioun of visible fier, ri&yogh;t as worchiþ þe fier of helle / And|þis priuytee is so vertuous, þat þe vertu þerof may not al be|declarid.  And þus it is maad.  Take Mercurie þat is sublymed| with vitriol, & comen salt, & sal armoniac .7. or .10. tymes|sublymed / and meynge hem togidere by euene porcioun. and|grynde it smal, and leye it abrood vpon a marbil stoon; and by|ny&yogh;te sette it in a soft cleer eir, or ellis in a coold seler; and þere|it wole turne into watir / And þanne gadere it togidere in to|a strong vessel of glas, and kepe it / This water forsoþe is so|strong, þat if a litil drope þerof falle vpon &yogh;oure hond, anoon it|wole perce it þoru&yogh;-out; and in þe same maner it wole do, if it|falle vpon a plate of venus or Iubiter, into þis watir, it turneþ|hem into lijknes of peerl. who so coude reparale & preparate|kyndely þis fier, wiþoute doute it wolde quenche anoon a brennynge|sijknes clepid þe fier of helle.  And also it wolde heele|euery cor[os]if sijknesse.  And manye philosophoris clepiþ þis|þing in her bookis 'sal amarus,' al þou&yogh; þei teche not þe maistrie|þerof / If it be so þat þis firy watir breke þe glas, and renne out|into þe aischen, þanne gadere alle togidere þat &yogh;e fynde pastid in|þe aischen / and leye it vpon a marbil stoon as afore, and it wole|turne into watir.  And þis is a greet priuytee.
0.11:
The science to brynge gold into calx / Take fyn gold, and|make it into smal lymayl: take a crusible wiþ a good quantitee|of Mercurie, and sette it to a litil fier so þat it vapoure|not, and putte þerinne þi lymail of gold, and stire it weel togidere| / & aftirward wiþinne a litil tyme &yogh;e schal se al þe gold|wiþinne þe Mercurie turned into erþe as sotil as flour. þanne|&yogh;eue it a good fier, þat þe Mercurie arise and go his wey; or ellis,
 |and &yogh;e wole, &yogh;e may distille and gadere it, puttynge þer-vpon a|lembike / and in þe corusible &yogh;e schal fynde þe gold calcyned and|reducid into erþe / And if &yogh;e wole not make lymayl of gold,|þanne make þerof a sotil þinne plate, as &yogh;e kan, and putte wiþinne|þe Mercurie al warm; and &yogh;e schal haue &yogh;oure desier / And|in þis same maner &yogh;e may worche wiþ siluir / Thanne take þe|calx of þese two bodies, and bere hem openly wiþ &yogh;ou; and þer|schal noman knowe what þei ben / And if &yogh;e wole bere hem|more priuyly wiþoute ony knowynge, þanne meynge hem wiþ|pich melt, or wex, or ellis gumme, for þanne noman schal knowe|it what it is.  And whanne &yogh;e wole dissolue ony of þese calces|by hem silf, putte eiþir by him silf in a test, or ellis þe pich or|þe wex in which þei ben ynne; and anoon schal come out verry|gold & siluer as þei were tofore.
0.12: Now I wole teche &yogh;ou þe maistrie of departynge of gold|fro siluir whanne þei be meyngid togidere / Forsoþe &yogh;e woot|weel þat þer be manye werkis in þe whiche gold and siluir|be meyngid, as in giltynge of vessel & Iewellis / þerfore|whanne &yogh;e wole drawe þe toon fro þat oþir, putte al þat mixture|into a strong watir maad of vitriol and of sal petre.  and þe siluyr wole be dissolued, and not þe gold: þanne &yogh;e haue þat |oon departid fro þe toþir / And if &yogh;e wole dissolue þe gold to|watir, putte þanne yn þe watir corosyue, Sal armoniac; and þat|watir wiþoute doute wole dissolue gold into watir.

1.2: The secunde medicyn is to heele a man, and make hym |lyue, þat is almoost consumed in nature, and so ny&yogh; deed þat|he is forsake of lechis. but if it be þe laste teerme of his lijf|sett of god, &yogh;e schal &yogh;eue him oure quinte essence of gold wiþ a|litil quantite of watir of celendoyn &yogh;drawe, and meynge it wiþ|þe oþere þingis aforeseid / and anoon as þe sike hath resceyued|it into his stomak, it &yogh;eueþ to þe herte influence of naturel heete|and of lijf. and þanne &yogh;e schal se him rise vp and speke, and|wondirfully be comfortid and strenkþid þerby // þanne comforte|him wiþ ministracioun of oure quinte essencie afore seid, and he|schal be al hool / but if it be so þat god wole algatis þat he schal|die /  And I seie to &yogh;ou truly, þat þis is þe hi&yogh;este maistrie þat|may be in transmutacioun of kynde; for ri&yogh;t fewe lechis now|lyuynge knowe þis priuytee.
1.3: The þridde medicyn is to cure þe lepre þat is causid of|corrupcioun and putrifaccioun of ony of þe principal humouris|of man; but not þe lepre þat comeþ to man of kynde of|þe fadir and of þe modir leprous,—for it is callid morbus|hereditus,—ne þe lepre þat is sent of god by his plage, but þat|þat is causid oonly of rotun humouris / take oure 5 essence|aforeseid, wiþ þe quinte essence of goold and peerl, a litil quantite|at oonys, and vse it in maner as I seide afore / and wiþinne a|fewe daies he schal be partily hool þerof. and if &yogh;e haue non|preparate redy oure 5 essence, þanne take in þe stide þerof fyn|brennynge watir / but þat oþer is bettere.
1.4: Also, drawe a water of þe fruy&yogh;t of strawbery or mulbery|tree, whanne it is ripe, and waische þe lepre þerwiþ. þis watir|is of so greet vertu; for a souereyn maistir took it a leprous| womman, þat wiþ þe waischinge oonly of þis watir, withynne|schort tyme was maad al hool / but sikirly þe vertu þerof is|myche worth if it be meyngid with oure 5 essence, or ellis|brennynge watir; and þanne it schal be no nede to vse in þis|perilous cure, venemys, as summe lechis doon.

1.10: The .8. medicyn for to cure the quarteyn and alle þe|passionns þat comeþ of malencoly in mannys body; and þe|maistrie to purge malencoly. and &yogh;e schal vndirstonde þat þe|quarteyn is gendrid of myche haboundaunce of malencolye þat|is corrumpid withynne þe body. and for þis humour is erþely,|coold, & drie, of þe nature of slowe saturne, þerfore þe accesse|of þis sijknes ben slowe, and it duriþ comounly yn a man a &yogh;eer|or more, and it puttiþ fro him gladnesse, & bryngiþ yn heuynes|more þan oþere feueris do /  If &yogh;e wole heele þis sijknes in schort|tyme, lete þe pacient vse to drynke oon ? our 5 essence, and he schal|be al hool hastily / forwhi; it consumeþ þe corrupt superflue|humouris, & reducit nature to equalite, and bryngiþ yn gladnesse,|& chasiþ a-wey heuynes & malencolie.  and if it so be|þat &yogh;e haue nou&yogh;t oure 5 essence / þanne take j lb of þe beste|brennynge watir, and þerinne putte medullam ebuli, and namely|þe white, if &yogh;e may may haue it / of þis watir &yogh;eue to þe pacient,|morowe and euen, a walnot-schelle ful at oonys. and he schal|be al hool / or ellis þus: take what þing &yogh;e wole þat purgiþ|malencolye, and putte a litil þerof into brennynge watir, &|vse þat laxatif maad into smale pelotis, wijsly resceyuyng ri&yogh;t a|litil at oonys, as oon litil pelot, and preue þerby how it worchiþ,|þanne anoþer tyme .ij. at oonys, if it be nede / so þat þe mater|be a litil digestid and a litil egestid. for bettere it is to worche|a litil & a litil at oonys, þan sodeynly greue þe nature. forwhi,| two litil pelotis laxatif meyngid wiþ brennynge watir wole|worche more my&yogh;tily þan .8. pelotis wole do bi hem silf /|Also philosophoris seyn þat a tooþ drawe out from a quyk|beest, born vpon a man, delyueriþ fro þe quarteyn /  Also|þei seyn þat if þe yuis of þe eerbe þat is callid morsus galline|rubri be putt in hise nose-þrillis whanne he bigynneth to suffre|þe accesse of þe quarteyn, he schal be hool, wiþ þe grace of|god.
1.11: The medicyn to heele þe feuere contynuele.  alle philosophoris|seyn þat þe feuere contynuele is gendrid of putrifaccioun|of blood and of corrupcieun of humouris in it /|þerfore þe cure þerof is to purge blood, and to putte awey þe|corrupcioun of it, & þe humoris vneuene to make euene,|þe nature lost to restore, and so restorid to kepe /  Forsoþe alle|þese þingis worcheþ oure quinte essence; and þerfore it curiþ|perfi&yogh;tly þe feuere contynuele / and þou&yogh; brennynge watir caste|out fro blood watry humouris and corrupt, &yogh;itt take it nou&yogh;t in|þis cure / forwhi; þou&yogh; brennynge watir be .7. tymes distillid,|&yogh;itt it is [not] fully depurid fro his brennynge heete, & þe .4.|elementis / but siþ oure 5. essence is not hoot, ne moist, coold,|ne drie, as ben þe 4. elementis / þerfore it heeliþ perfi&yogh;tly þe|contynuel feuere; namely wiþ commixtioun of þe 5 essence of|gold & peerle / and if &yogh;e wole strenkþe &yogh;oure medicyn, þanne|putte yn oure 5. essence a litil quantite of pulpa cassie fistule /|or ellis þe iuys of þe eerbe mercuriale. & if it so be þat oþere|humouris habounde to myche with blood, þanne take þo laxatyues|þat kyndely wole purge hem, as comoun bookis of |fisik declareþ.
